In order to absorb CO2 on a large scale, several nanocatalysts have been developed as fuel conversion technologies in response to an increase in the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere. MXene is a young family of two-dimensional metal carbides and nitrides. MXene-based catalysts are nominated for divers who require applications. The selectivity of MXene with high CO2 adsorption capacity, charge carrier, high separation rate, and efficient CO2 conversion efficiency has led to the wide application of MXene and MXene photocatalyst in recent CO2 reduction studies. The specialty of MXene, such as high electrical conductivity, large active area, and large area size, makes MXene a candidate co-catalyst. Although commonly used as a co-catalyst in photocatalytic CO2 reduction, the basic mechanism of MXene is still unknown. Theoretical and computational modeling (first-principle density functional theory) is quite effective to understand how MXene and MXene-based photocatalysts affect CO2 reduction. This is supported by the results of further research. In addition to the simulation and calculation, steps of completely understanding the relationship between the layer structure and the phase and determining the type of MXene, the surface functional group, and the characteristics there between may facilitate the achievement of the goals. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Mxene Synthesis Co2 reduction Catalyst Monolith reactor Fixed-bed reactor Hydrogenation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Burning fossil fuels to produce energy has a significant impact on issues such as climate change and global warming, and broadly research is being done to manage the accumulation of large amounts of CO2 and recover it as fuel. However, research on converting CO2 into pure and continuous production fuel by electrocatalytic and photocatalytic methods is still limited [1–3]. Hydrogenation of CO2 to catalysts led to the formation of various products, of which methanol is the product obtained from catalysts. Since the above-described method is directly proportional to the structure and composition of the catalyst used, various types of efficient and inexpensive catalyst material may be used. Various active hetero catalysts, including the combination of Ni, Cu, Co, Mn, Fe, and ZnZr, were observed as effective catalysts from photocatalytic CO2 reduction (CO2R) to methanol. Specifically, examples of the high active CO2 conversion catalyst include Cu/ZnO/Al2O3, Cu-ZnO-ZrO2, Cu/CeO2, and FeOCeO2 [4,5]. However, these catalysts still have low methanol selectivity and CO2 capture problems despite their increased activity. In addition to the metal-oxide (MO) catalyst, inert supports such as AC, silica, zeolite, 2D ceramic nanomaterials, graphene, and hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) have been widely studied, and 2D materials can inhibit substantial agglomeration of metal alloy nanoparticles and increase catalytic activity and selectivity. Metal-organic framework (MOF) and double metal-oxide/sulfide (DMO/sulfide) are actively used due to the highlighted features in the search for photocatalysts capable of efficient CO2 reduction. The highlighted features included the following: 1. an abundance sites, 2. The large specific surface area, 3. a short range of photogenerated charge carriers, and 4. ease of loading on other catalysts in various ways [6–12]. 2D material member MXene has recently emerged as a high performance system for catalyst applications due to its unique features such as large surface area, adjustable structure, surface hydrophilicity and high metal conductivity [13,14]. A new type of 2D material called MXenes has received a lot of attention since the first-work of Gogotsi et al. on the synthesis of 2D Ti3C2 in 2011 [15–19]. Successful synthesis of M2X, M3×2, M4×3, and M5C4 showed that the structural diversity of MXene was constantly increasing. MXene generally has mechanical elasticity, improves the electrical conductivity of metals and ions, and absorbs electromagnetic waves [20–23]. By using class, A selective etching, the MAX phases (Mn+1AXn) are converted to MXene (Mn+1XnTx). Ti3C2Tx-based 2D MXene nanosheets (where Tx represents the surface-terminated functional groups of -O, -OH and -F) were produced by selectively etching the Al layer from Ti3AlC2 using HF-etching. Thus, the MXene material has been found to be a perfect auxiliary catalyst and/or catalyst supporter to improve the performance of CO2R due to its unique properties. According to the studies conducted and published papers, MXene can increase charge separation, reduce optical corrosion, and promote adsorption and activation, thereby increasing CO2 catalyst efficiency. CO2 improves the light response in the visible light spectrum, while at the same time. In addition to these factors, MXene nanocomposites may improve the photothermal effect of metal NP and activate the photothermal reaction of CO2. However, much remains to be done to improve performance, selectivity, and reliability. Existing papers are limited to a small number of MXene materials, mainly Ti3C2, although the design of MXene-based photocatalysts is still in its early stages, and frequently focuses on the involvement of MXene in certain stages rather than complete photocatalytic processes [24–29]. Given the rapid advancements in this area and the advantageous uses of Ti3C2Tx (MXene) in catalyst field, there is an urgent need for a thorough analysis of photocatalyst based on MXene (Ti3C2Tx). In order to improve performance and practical applications, it is essential to examine the exact properties of MXenes-materials, including the interaction between MXenes and guest materials and the preservation of physical and mechanical properties of MXenes. Therefore, this paper provides and short and in-depth discussion of the most recent developments in Ti3C2Tx-based photocatalysts and it focuses on the important role played by Ti3C2Tx in achieving exceptional catalytic activity, along with related concepts. 2 Advances on the catalytic conversion of CO2 In the heterogeneous CO2 catalysis, semiconductors were used as active photocatalysts [30]. Electrons from the valence band (VB) to the conduction band (CB) are excited by light with an energy greater than the band gap, forming electron-hole pairs that split and move to surface active sites to start redox reactions. [31–35]. As indicated in the introduction, MXenes have been shown to perform various functions in CO2 photocatalysis as a co-catalyst for semiconductors. 2.1 Enhancement of photgenerated charge carrier separation Due to the rapid recombination of charge carriers, the performance of semiconductor photocatalysts (SPs) is often limited by the extremely short life of photochemically excited electron-hole pairs [29]. Since the EF of MXene is generally more positive than the CB of SP, the transfer of photochemically excited electrons from semiconductors to MXene is facilitated [36]. The reduction half-reaction of CO2 is activated by the subsequent injection of photoexcited electrons into the adsorbed CO2, while the oxidation half-reaction is facilitated by a hole in the semiconductor surface (Fig. 1 ). That is, in the CO2 photocatalyst of the MXene-SP complex, MXene often acts as both an electron carrier and an active site. For example, Yu et al. noted that the very high conductivity of Ti3C2, which accelerates the transport of photogenic electrons and reduces recombination with photogenic holes, is responsible for the excellent photocatalytic performance of TiO2/Ti3C2 complexes [37]. Fig. 3 shows the pore size distribution curve related to the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the sample. According to the BDDT classification, all samples showed type IV isotherms, indicating the presence of mesopores (2–50 nm). Type IV isotherms occur when capillary condensation occurs. Gases condense in the tiny capillary pores of the solid at pressures below the saturation pressure of the gas. In the lower pressure regions, it shows monolayer formation followed by multilayer formation. BET surface characterization of mesoporous materials, which are materials with pore diameters between 2 and 50 nm, gives this type of isotherm. The isotherms in the 0.8–1.0 relative pressure range show an H3-type hysteresis loop indicating the presence of slit-like holes [38]. Because of the problem, additional studies have been conducted, and it is known that if the charge generated from unstable NP is efficiently transferred to MXene through the interface layer between MXene, the photochemical capability and activity could be increased. In addition, many cracks can be found on TT650. 2.3 Inhibition of photo corrosion Among the semiconductors used in photocatalytic research, TiO2 is the most stable, while other general semiconductors, such as Ag3PO4 and Cu2O [40,41], undergo photo corrosion and additionally decrease in photocatalytic activity depending on the effect of photogenerated charge carriers [42–44]. An optimal way to prevent the above phenomenon is to improve both the catalytic activity and photo-stability by connecting the semiconductor with another catalyst or using MXene as a co-catalyst and transferring the photogenerated electrons in the semiconductor to the co-catalyst. 2.4 CO2 reduction Fig. 4 shows the photoreduction reactor used in the CO2 experiment, which was classified as a monolith and fixed bed. As shown in Fig. 4a, the catalyst material was uniformly distributed in the fixed-layer reactor, and only the catalyst surface acted as the primary active site of CO2R. Therefore, a process of reducing gas absorption and light absorption on the surface was performed. Experiments from CO2R to CH4 were performed at various intensities of light in a fixed-bed reactor. We note that increasing the intensity of light from 20 mW cm−2 to 100 mW cm−2 causes more photons to bounce off the catalyst surface, increase electron production, and increase CH4 formation efficiently. However, since the light transmission in the electrode reactor is weak and most of the light reflected at the top of the monolith reactor, only adsorption of the reducing agent gas has been suggested due to the lack of a photocatalytic process [45]. A various materials have been used in CO2R. The first is a single-particulate photocatalyst system via one-photon excitation, in which photocatalytic reduction by photogenerated electrons and photocatalytic oxidation by photogenerated holes proceed on one particle. Photocatalysts of semiconductor materials have a band structure in which a CB is separated from a VB with a band gap (BG). The thermodynamic relationship between the band structure of a photocatalyst and the redox potential for the objective reaction is important. The second is a Z-scheme system via a two-photon excitation process consisting of a reducing photocatalyst, an oxidizing photocatalyst, and an electron mediator. This system mimics natural photosynthesis by a plant. Various photocatalysts that are active for either photocatalytic reduction of water and CO2 reduction or photocatalytic oxidation of water can be employed to make a Z-scheme system. From this viewpoint, it is meaningful to test photocatalytic CO2 reduction using sacrificial electron donors such as organic compounds and S2– in order to find potential CO2-reducing photocatalysts in a part of the Z scheme system, though the sacrificial reaction becomes a downhill reaction (ΔG < 0). In addition, it is a key issue to construct visible light responsive CO2 reduction system using water as an electron donor for efficient sunlight utilization beyond the wide band gap photocatalysts. The reduction potential of single-electron CO2 reduction reaction requires a highly negative potential of −1.9 eV, which makes the one-electron reduction process very unfavorable. On the other hand, the proton assisted multi-electron CO2 reduction reaction requires comparatively low redox potential and are more favorable. Photocatalysts can facilitate these reduction processes with lower potential. For this purpose, an ideal photocatalyst generally requires two characteristics: (i) the redox potential of the photo-excited VB hole must be sufficiently positive so that the hole can act as an electron acceptor; and (ii) the redox potentials of the photo-excited CB electron must be more negative than that of the CO2/reduced-product redox couple. When the photocatalytic reduction reaction gives complex products, then the number of reacted electrons in the equation denotes the sum of the reacted electron to form each product. Thus, in light-based measurements, the quantum yield of CO2 photo-reduction into different products can be calculated using following equations: (2) Overall quantum yield ( % ) = Number of reacted electrons Number of absorbed photons × 100 % (3) Apparent quantum yield ( QY , % ) = Number of reacted electrons Number of incident photons × 100 % (4) ( Apparent ) quantum yield of CO ( % ) = 2 × Number of CO molecules Number of incident photons × 100 % (5) ( Apparent ) quantum yield of HCOOH ( % ) = 2 × Number of HCOOH molecules Number of incident photons × 100 % (6) ( Apparent ) quantum yield of HCHO ( % ) = 4 × Number ofHCHO molecules Number of incident photons × 100 % (7) ( Apparent ) quantum yield of CH 3 OH ( % ) = 6 × Number of CH 3 OH molecules Number of incident photons × 100 % (8) ( Apparent ) quantum yield of CH 4 ( % ) = 8 × Number of CH 4 molecules Number of incident photons × 100 % 2.5 Improving CO2 gas adsorption and activation The adsorption and activation of CO2 on a catalyst surface is the initial step. The activation of adsorbed CO2 molecules is a crucial and very challenging step for CO2 reduction. CO2 adsorption and activation significantly affect subsequent reduction steps and suppression of the competing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). The adsorption interaction with surface atoms is believed to result in a partially charged species CO2 δ −. The possible adsorbed structures of CO2 mainly include oxygen coordination, carbon coordination, and mixed coordination (in Fig. 5 ). For oxygen coordination, each of the oxygen atoms in CO2 can donate lone pairs of electrons to surface Lewis acid centers (in Fig. 5a). For carbon coordination, the carbon atom in CO2 could also behave as a Lewis acid and acquire electrons from Lewis base sites, resulting in a carbonate-like structure (in Fig. 5b). In contrast, for mixed coordination, both oxygen atoms and carbon atoms in CO2 act as electron donors and acceptors at the same time, as shown in Fig. 5c [46]. The overall photocatalytic effectiveness is greatly influenced by the kinetics of surface redox events in addition to light absorption and charge separation [47]. The efficiency of CO2R can be increased by promoting the passage of electrons from the catalytic active sites to CO2 by providing enough space for the CO2 molecules to adsorb [87]. The MXenes generally accept photoelectrons when combined with SP, serving as an active CO2 reduction site. In this situation, the generous and controllable surface functional groups of the MXene material provide a convenient way to enhance CO2 adsorption and activation, thereby improving photocatalytic performance. Wang et al. reported that Ti3C2 MXene with surface alkalized for CO2R is a highly efficient, precious metal-free cocatalyst for commercial titania (P25) [48]. Ti3C2 MXene with an alkalized surface for CO2R was found to be a very effective precious metal-free co-catalyst for commercial titanium dioxide (P25), according to Wang et al. The -OH surface anchor groups increased when KOH was coated on the Ti3C2 surface, converting them to primary sites for acidic CO2 adsorption. This study confirmed this procedure, with a CO2 adsorption peak of 7.01 cm3 g/g, as shown in Fig. 6 a. Therefore, the adsorption energy (Eads) of CO2 on the -F or -OH group at the Ti3C2 MXene was calculated by DFT. As shown in Fig. 6, the Eads of CO2 on the -F group of MXene were higher than the Eads of CO2 on the -OH group. The smooth surface of MXene and the accumulation of many electrons allow for the transfer of many charges, significantly speeding up the CO2R reaction producing CH4. Yu et al. achieved similar results when they found that Ti3C2 MXene enhanced CO2 absorption and activation, increasing the efficiency of Bi2WO6 nanosheets in CO2R [49]. 2.6 Photocatalysis of CO2 in gas phase Tahir et al. created a composite with structure TiO2/g-C3N4/Ti3C2 (TgCNTC) in 2020 to regenerate CO2R of CH4 under visible-light [39]. Because TC-MXene has a special structure, it maximizes electron transport across the heterojunction by reducing the distance that photoexcited electrons must travel and increasing the junction area. As a result, the CO and H2 generation rates of the TgCNTC mixture were 48.4 and 83.2 mol g−1 without a loss of activation, respectively, 5.2 and 9.9 times higher than that of TiO2 (Fig. 7 ). Recently, some of us have investigated how to use Nb2C-MXene and TC-MXene in photocatalytic CO2H. Nb2C was found to be ineffective as a one-component catalyst for the photothermal hydrogenation of CO2 while having exceptional photothermal properties. A significant improvement in photothermal catalytic efficiency was observed when Ni nanoparticles were loaded into Nb2C. The stable carbon dioxide conversion rate of the Ni/Nb2C catalyst is 1.4 mol g−1h−1, a 5-fold increase compared to the rate of the Nb2O5-supported Ni catalyst with structure, size and electrical properties. This is achieved by the excellent light absorption of Nb2C. In addition, the Nb2C-supported Ni nanoparticles were able to convert CO2 at a rate of 8.50 mol g−1h−1 under 36 h light without the use of additional heat (Fig. 7). According to investigations on photothermal and thermal catalysis, the Nb2C MXene support was able to efficiently stabilize Ni NPs against sintering. For photothermal CO2 hydrogenation, TC-MXene was also found to be a superior support material over Nb2C as a single component catalyst. 2.7 Liquid-phase CO2 photocatalysis Liquid phase systems have been used for the majority of studies on the use of MXenes in CO2R [50,51]. For example, Yu et al. demonstrated how TiO2 (NP) of highly conductive TC-MXene can be grown in the field using calcination processes to generate unique rice flour-like structures with a uniform distribution of TiO2 NP on TC [89]. The evolution rate of CH4 for the TiO2/TC composite was 3.7 times higher than that of commercial P25 (Fig. 8 a) as the specific surface area increased and the electron-hole separation efficiency improved, and CH4 did not change even after the 5-cycling test (Fig. 8b). An ultra-thin 2D/2D TCgCN heterojunction photocatalyst was recently developed by Lv and co-authors [52]. The total CO2 conversion rate of the TCgCN heterojunction was 9.1 times higher than that of pure gCN due to fast charge separation and CO2 activation. 2.8 CO2 hydrogenattion (CO2H) to methanol An effective way to reduce climate change from sustainable liquid fuel production and CO2 emissions in the energy and environment sectors is to hydrogenate CO2 into other chemicals. Recently, efforts have been made to develop an alkaline hydroxide-based method for converting CO2H into methanol using the MXene-based catalyst system [22,50,53]. Strangely, a process in which CO2 is efficiently converted into methanol in a manufactured catalyst is schematized as illustrated in Fig. 9 , and while NaBH4 generates H2 in a reactor, CO is collected using EG as a solvent. The remarkable CO2 conversion efficiency of 28% was demonstrated by delamination catalyst MXene NSs with significant amounts of formic acid (2%), CH3OH (23%), CH4 and CO (4%). An important role in hydrogenation is particularly due to the production of site H2 of NaBH4 in the reactor [29]. In addition, the selectivity of MXene, Pd50-Ru50, and Pd50-Ru50/MXene was estimated to be 88, 87, and 99%, respectively, and the total rotation (TON) values of these catalysts were set to 120, 1810, and 2932, respectively. Due to the special density of the basic site, Pd50-Ru50 NP, which is well dispersed on the MXene NS, has a higher number of TONs, which clearly improves CO2H. Fig. 10 shows the overall process of CO2H over the Pd-Ru/MXene catalyst. In the process, two key factors have been nominated such as (i) the dosage rate of Pd-Ru on TC and (ii) effective active sites of TC-MXene as an imparted part to enhance the selectivity of the product [54]. Theoretically, Ru metal has the potential to support formate selectivity, thereby enhancing methanol production. In addition, Pd has the potential to convert CO2 to CH4 more effectively than other Me [55]. The junction of Pd and Ru facilitated the easy splitting of H2 molecules into atomically activated H* atoms, which then spilled over to the MXene surfaces at a lower temperature [56]. On the MXene surface, the diffusely reactive H* atoms react with the adsorbed CO2 molecules to produce HCOO*, followed by the subsequent synthesis of H2COO*. Methanol will then form by the reaction of H2COO* with too many H* atoms to produce H2CO* combined with H2O on the surface of MXene [57]. The MXene-based catalyst materials studied for CO2 reduction to hydrocarbon fuels and other products are summarized in Table 1 . As shown in Table 1, MXene has a high potential to improve the catalyst activity, charge carrier, and overall characteristics of the neighboring catalyst as a co-catalyst. 3 Synthesis and methodology Since the first report of Ti3C2Tx MXene was published in 2011, unprecedented types of MXene, including mono and multi-element TM-carbohydrates and nitrides, have been investigated. Other methods used to manufacture molten salt [76–78], chemical vapor deposition [79,80], electrochemical etching [81], wet etching [81–84], and MXene are summarized in Fig. 11 . Top-down and bottom-up approaches have been used in MXene-synthesis, among which top-down approaches are commonly used in the synthesis of MXene. This integrated path differs from other methods in that it can be extended without losing or changing properties as the size of the MXene package increases. Although the top-down method is widely used in MXene-manufacturing, the bottom-up method has been newly developed. The bottom-up approach focuses on transforming nanoscale inorganic molecules into larger molecular structures, specifically including chemical vapor deposition (CVD), template methods, and plasma enhanced pulse laser deposition (PEPLD) [85,86]. In 2015, Xu et al. first reported the production of high-quality ultra-thin molybdenum carbide (Mo2C) crystals using CVD [87]. Subsequently, in 2017, a prototype MXene synthesis method was developed in which carbonization/nitrification was performed after using a 2D transition metal oxide nanosheet as a template. Xiao et al. developed a scalable and efficient salt simulation method for the synthesis of 2D MoN nanosheets [88]. In addition, the PEPLD synthesis method was reported by Zhang et al. in 2017, who used Mo2C crystals to produce [89]. The 3D crystal layered carbide and nitride layers, mainly MAX phases, are selectively etched to produce top-down MXenes. Group A elements, generally group 13 to 16 elements, are bonded to Mn+1Xn class atoms in a MAX phase. Fig. 12 a illustrates three different types of MAX phase structures: M2AX, M3AX2, and M4AX3. Elemental powder sintering of MAX phases in stoichiometric ratios, such as 3M:1A:2C for M3AC2, at temperatures above 1300 °C in a controlled environment is the typical method for forming out these phases. Fig. 12c shows a list of elements for the M, X, T and some of group A for MAX-phases [90]. Ideas for synthesizing MXenes are often based on single transition metals, but recently, more attention has been paid to the preparation of MXenes based on double transition metals [17–21]. The search for double transition metal-based MXenes has become a focus of MXene synthesis ideas, which have progressed beyond the single transition metal-based MXene [91]. To make the whole process non-toxic, alternatives to the HF-based selective corrosion process are being investigated. For example, when Ti3AlC2 is etched in HF solution at ambient temperature, the surface of the carbide layer is terminated by O, OH and/or F atoms, which selectively remove A (Al) atoms. In addition to solvent treatment of HF, various reagents and ions, DMSO [92], TBAOH [93], alkali metal ions [94], and ultrasound treatment methods have been reported in recent studies. Ti3C2 MXene was first reported in 2011 by dipping Ti3AlC2 MAX powder into a 50% concentrated HF solution. The final MXene exhibits an accordion-like layered structure with multiple functional groups. The equations below represent the general chemical reactions of the etching process. (9) M n + 1 A l X n + 3 H F = A l F 3 + 3 / 2 H 2 + M n + 1 X n (10) M n + 1 X n + 2 H 2 O = M n + 1 X n ( O H ) 2 + H 2 (11) M n + 1 X n + 2 H F = M n + 1 X n F 2 + H 2 The final MXene exhibits an accordion-like layered structure with multiple functional groups. In addition to treatment with potent HF etching agents, HF etching treatment on MAX was also indirectly reported by Gogotsi and Barsoom in 2014 [94]. In order to prepare Ti3C2Tx, Ti2CTx, and V2CTx, in addition to LiF/HCl mixed solvents, fluoride salt/HCl mixed solvents such as NaF, KF, NH4F, FeF3/HCl and fluorine-containing ammonium salts were used. The advantage of this method is that the etch layer removal process is developed in a single step, and the whole synthesis route leads to a reduction in the high consumption of HF. The interlayer spacing of MXene increases due to the interaction of Li+ and NH4 + ions. Therefore, only manual or ultrasonic stirring is required to disintegrate the product into a monolayer film. All of the above-mentioned methods used HF or F-containing etching agents, which led to the excessive use of F-based etching agents, causing serious safety and environmental problems. Because of this major problem, research into the use of fluorine-free cites for the development of MXenes is becoming increasingly popular. The use of Lewis acidic molten salts for the preparation of MXene has been reported from various MAX and A-elements such as Zn (Ti3ZnC2), Al (Ti2AlC), Si (Ti3SiC2), and Ga (Ti2GaC). This etching technique offers remarkable possibilities for tuning the surface chemistry and properties of MXenes, as well as the creation of new MXenes that cannot be prepared during etching. Imprint/stamping techniques are replacing traditional electrode preparation methods for scaling devices for homogeneous mass production [95–98] (as shown in Fig. 13 ). 4 Recent trends in Ti3C2 as a co-catalyst for solar fuels MXene Ti3C2 exhibits properties such as conductivity, metallic nature, surface, and functional groups as termination, making it an outstanding co-catalyst in various photocatalytic processes. In addition, the low value of the Fermi level and the ability of Ti3C2 to accept/capture electrons make it advantageous to work efficiently for the separation of electron-hole pairs. Also the increased surface area and exposed active reaction sites with a multilayer structure with different morphologies are another advantage that supports good dispersion of photocatalysts on its surface and improves reaction kinetics and charge mobility as shown in Fig. 14 a. Therefore, it is often used as a cocatalyst to improve photocatalytic efficiency [98]. Furthermore, Fig. 14b summarizes the functional aspects of using Ti3C2 for solar-to-energy conversion applications. The layered morphology of Ti3C2 offers a specific surface area with functional groups as terminations on its surface, enabling excellent adsorption of reactants for photocatalytic activities. For example, chromium(VI) was photo reduced in the presence of Ti3C2 based on negatively charged Ti3C2 adsorbing the positively charged metals [99]. The optimization of HER activity was achieved by co-catalyst Ti3C2 with CdS, which is attributed to the existence of an O-termination on the surface of Ti3C2 to provide electrons for reduction of protons. As shown in Fig. 14c, for improved thermodynamics of the reaction, O-terminated Ti3C2 showed a very low Gibbs free energy for HER, i.e., as shown in Fig. 14d. Recently, in a study on photocatalytic H2 evolution, a one-dimensional (1D) CdS/2D Ti3C2 heterojunction prevented charge recombination by accepting electrons from CB of CdS and overall reducing the Schottky barrier of the interface [100]. Similarly, Chao et al. reported 2D/2D Ti3C2/g C3N4, in which Ti3C2 acted as an electron acceptor due to its conductivity to carry out the CO2 reduction reaction, as shown in Fig. 14e [101]. Many studies have reported that Ti3C2 is a support material for uniformly dispersing other photocatalysts without aggregation to impart reduced particle size to the dispersed photocatalysts. This can be attributed to the increased surface area and functional group on the surface of Ti3C2 together with the mechanical stability offered. As shown in Fig. 14f, the photocatalytic CO2 reduction of well-dispersed TiO2 on Ti3C2 was investigated. The improved CO2 photoactivity was associated with a higher number of active sites exposed to reactants because of the good interaction of Ti3C2 with the photocatalyst and also because of the reduced particle size of the photocatalyst [102]. Furthermore, the electronegativity of Ti3C2 enables metal adsorption to suppress photocatalyst agglomeration [103]. Layered Ti3C2 with a band gap of 0.75 eV is known to respond to visible light, while Ti3C2 also shows the photoreaction along with visible light absorption. In addition, the black color of Ti3C2 makes it very sensitive to light absorption [104]. Li et al. reported water splitting by Ti3C2/TiO2, where Ti3C2 showed insignificant absorption of the UV spectrum, while the visible light spectrum was efficiently absorbed because of its dark color. In addition, the synthesis of Ti3C2 nanoflowers enhanced the light absorption of the whole composite due to better light reflection [105]. In another study, the photoactivity of g-C3N4 with Ti3C2 cocatalyst was enhanced due to the enhanced light collection as a dark color and metallic nature that Ti3C2 did brought to use light across the UV and visible spectrum. 5 Conclusions Semiconductor materials are important for environmental problems and energy solutions as they can optically convert CO2 into useful solar fuels using visible light to simulate natural photosynthesis. MXene is a strong candidate to support CO2R as a co-catalyst due to its high electrical conductivity, numerous active sites, and significant surface area. Recently, many studies have been conducted on DFT of MXene, a mixture of semiconductors and single atoms, emphasizing the importance of structural defects and impurities as well as the production of MXene. One of unique properties of MXene is its excellent light absorption, and this selectivity can be further improved by controlling the synergy effect by including multiple deformation paths. The interaction of additional catalysts with MXene resulted in various charge transfer processes, and Z-scheme is one of the mechanisms that can determine the overall mechanism. MXene cannot form Z-scheme directly when combined with semiconductors, but it should be sought in future studies to introduce it into Z-scheme heterojunction. It should be noted that the fast recombination speed of the Z-scheme can disrupt the balance between the internal electric field and the potential difference. coredata.dc:description: In order to absorb CO2 on a large scale, several nanocatalysts have been developed as fuel conversion technologies in response to an increase in the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere. MXene is a young family of two-dimensional metal carbides and nitrides. MXene-based catalysts are nominated for divers who require applications. The selectivity of MXene with high CO2 adsorption capacity, charge carrier, high separation rate, and efficient CO2 conversion efficiency has led to the wide application of MXene and MXene photocatalyst in recent CO2 reduction studies. The specialty of MXene, such as high electrical conductivity, large active area, and large area size, makes MXene a candidate co-catalyst. Although commonly used as a co-catalyst in photocatalytic CO2 reduction, the basic mechanism of MXene is still unknown. Theoretical and computational modeling (first-principle density functional theory) is quite effective to understand how MXene and MXene-based photocatalysts affect CO2 reduction. This is supported by the results of further research. In addition to the simulation and calculation, steps of completely understanding the relationship between the layer structure and the phase and determining the type of MXene, the surface functional group, and the characteristics there between may facilitate the achievement of the goals.
coredata.dc:title: MXene-based nanocomposite for the photocatalytic CO2 reduction: Comprehensive review
